episodes.description: The CITIUS MAG team unpacks all of the action from the first day of the U.S. Olympic Trials in Eugene, Oregon. A few of the most notable moments + highlights include:  – Men’s 10,000m final: The first final of the Trials is in the books! Grant Fisher pulled away from the field with three laps to go to take the 10,000m title in 27:49.47. – Women’s 100m 1st round: Sha’Carri Richardson leads all qualifiers to the 100m semifinal in 10.88 (with an untied shoe!). – Men’s 1500m 1st round: Cole Hocker runs 3:34.54 to lead the rest of the field to the 1500m semifinal. – Women’s 400m 1st round: Shamier Little drops a season’s best of 50.13 to advance to the 400m semifinal as the fastest seed. – Women’s 5000m: Elle St. Pierre blasts around the field to take the top qualifying spot into the 5000m final. + More _________ We’re popping up with New Balance live from Eugene for the most thrilling 10 days of track and field in America. We’re servin’ track and field scoops with our coverage. Catch us at the CITIUS MAG Scoop (presented by New Balance) pop-up right next to Prince Puckler’s Ice Cream at 19th Avenue and Agate Street – just a two-minute walk from Hayward Field. We’re hosting three shows a day on the CITIUS MAG YouTube channel. You’ll be able to find many of the shows under our “Live” tab on our channel. LIVE SHOWS Good Morning Track and Field will start your day with some takes and updates from Eugene hosted by Eric Jenkins, Mitch Dyer and Karen Lesiewicz at 8:30 a.m. PT. TRIALS TALK – our hit daily podcast series from 2021 – returns on The CITIUS MAG Podcast feed + streaming live immediately post-race to unpack all of the action immediately following the meet. LIVE MEET COVERAGE Stay updated on live results, mixed zone interviews and more on the CITIUS MAG Instagram, X and Threads pages while the meet is underway each evening. All interviews will be uploaded to our aforementioned YouTube channel. MORNING RUNS CITIUS MAG and New Balance will be hosting group runs on Sunday, June 23rd at 8 a.m. ET; Tuesday, June 25th at 8 a.m. and Saturday, June 29th at 7:30 a.m. Come on by to our pop-up next to Prince Puckler’s Ice Cream shop to meet for some easy morning miles. All paces are welcome. We’ll be giving away shirts, hats and more. Plus, you’ll have an opportunity to try all of the latest and greatest from New Balance. We’ll also have Olipop, coffee, games and cold plunges to enjoy afterward. Also, CITIUS MAG Newsletter subscribers will be getting daily emails from the Trials as David Melly rounds up all of the biggest results, stories + our best interviews, photos and original content from Eugene. If you want to hook a friend, there’s no better time than the Trials so forward them the emails or encourage them to sign up today for FREE here: https://citiusmag.beehiiv.com/ SUPPORT OUR SPONSORS 👟 NEW BALANCE: Discover the ultimate running shoe: Fresh Foam X 1080. With unbeatable comfort and top-tier performance, it's perfect for any occasion, from daily runs to races. Its innovative design includes Fresh Foam X midsole for seamless transitions and a breathable, supportive mesh upper. ⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠Visit NewBalance.com/Running⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠

episodes.description: Jacob Kiplimo and Beatrice Chebet repeated at World XC but what happened to Agnes Ngetich and Joshua Cheptegei? April Fools came and went and what were the craziest stories in the sport in the last year? And it's not an April Fools joke that a Texas A&M Aggie ran an NCAA leading 1:44:46 and may be a dark horse candidate at the Olympic Trials. Jacob Kiplimo and Beatrice Chebet repeated at World XC but what happened to Agnes Ngetich and Joshua Cheptegei?

episodes.description: Jimmy Gressier, qui espère s’aligner sur le 5 000 m et le 10 000 m aux JO de Paris, est originaire du quartier du Chemin Vert, à Boulogne-sur-Mer. Dans « Quartiers Olympiques », il raconte son enfance difficile dans cette commune du Pas-de-Calais, les obstacles qu’il a du surmonter avec ses frères et sœurs, et son admiration pour les dockers. Interview et écriture : Apolline Convain. Montage : Léa Leostic. Création musicale : Matthieu Roques Lago. Rédaction en chef : Jean-Philippe Leclaire et Gaëtan Scherrer. Extraits : la chaine L’Equipe et « Dans la tête d’un lion ».Hébergé par Ausha. Visitez ausha.co/politique-de-confidentialite pour plus d'informations.

episodes.description: The CITIUS MAG team unpacks all of the action from the first day of the U.S. Olympic Trials in Eugene, Oregon. A few of the most notable moments + highlights include:  – Men’s 10,000m final: The first final of the Trials is in the books! Grant Fisher pulled away from the field with three laps to go to take the 10,000m title in 27:49.47. – Women’s 100m 1st round: Sha’Carri Richardson leads all qualifiers to the 100m semifinal in 10.88 (with an untied shoe!). – Men’s 1500m 1st round: Cole Hocker runs 3:34.54 to lead the rest of the field to the 1500m semifinal. – Women’s 400m 1st round: Shamier Little drops a season’s best of 50.13 to advance to the 400m semifinal as the fastest seed. – Women’s 5000m: Elle St. Pierre blasts around the field to take the top qualifying spot into the 5000m final. + More _________ We’re popping up with New Balance live from Eugene for the most thrilling 10 days of track and field in America. We’re servin’ track and field scoops with our coverage. Catch us at the CITIUS MAG Scoop (presented by New Balance) pop-up right next to Prince Puckler’s Ice Cream at 19th Avenue and Agate Street – just a two-minute walk from Hayward Field. We’re hosting three shows a day on the CITIUS MAG YouTube channel. You’ll be able to find many of the shows under our “Live” tab on our channel. LIVE SHOWS Good Morning Track and Field will start your day with some takes and updates from Eugene hosted by Eric Jenkins, Mitch Dyer and Karen Lesiewicz at 8:30 a.m. PT. TRIALS TALK – our hit daily podcast series from 2021 – returns on The CITIUS MAG Podcast feed + streaming live immediately post-race to unpack all of the action immediately following the meet. LIVE MEET COVERAGE Stay updated on live results, mixed zone interviews and more on the CITIUS MAG Instagram, X and Threads pages while the meet is underway each evening. All interviews will be uploaded to our aforementioned YouTube channel. MORNING RUNS CITIUS MAG and New Balance will be hosting group runs on Sunday, June 23rd at 8 a.m. ET; Tuesday, June 25th at 8 a.m. and Saturday, June 29th at 7:30 a.m. Come on by to our pop-up next to Prince Puckler’s Ice Cream shop to meet for some easy morning miles. All paces are welcome. We’ll be giving away shirts, hats and more. Plus, you’ll have an opportunity to try all of the latest and greatest from New Balance. We’ll also have Olipop, coffee, games and cold plunges to enjoy afterward. Also, CITIUS MAG Newsletter subscribers will be getting daily emails from the Trials as David Melly rounds up all of the biggest results, stories + our best interviews, photos and original content from Eugene. If you want to hook a friend, there’s no better time than the Trials so forward them the emails or encourage them to sign up today for FREE here: https://citiusmag.beehiiv.com/ SUPPORT OUR SPONSORS 👟 NEW BALANCE: Discover the ultimate running shoe: Fresh Foam X 1080. With unbeatable comfort and top-tier performance, it's perfect for any occasion, from daily runs to races. Its innovative design includes Fresh Foam X midsole for seamless transitions and a breathable, supportive mesh upper. ⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠Visit NewBalance.com/Running⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠

episodes.description: “I definitely feel like having that success indoors with the two titles helped me gain confidence in my ability to close down a race and win a race in any way. Whether it’s a fast race, slow race, I'm equally as confident. For the rest of the outdoor season, it definitely helped me be not as concerned as the gun went off that I was going to be able to close well off of any kind of race.” Newly minted Olympian Nico Young joins the show after qualifying for his first Olympic team in the 10,000m at the 2024 U.S. Olympic Trials. He also just announced signing a professional contract with adidas. Nico unpacks his third-place finish in the 10,000m, recaps his incredible NCAA season, shares about his excitement for Paris, breaks down his Mount Rushmore of NAU distance running legends, and lots more. Hear more from Nico in this episode of the CITIUS MAG Podcast. episodes.description: Explore lives and careers of top flutistsHighlight their artistry and technical masteryShowcase their contributions to flute pedagogyInspire generations of flutists          .done-button-podcast {     display: inline-flex;     align-items: center;     margin: 4px 0 0;     padding: 4px 8px;     background: #622bff;     border: none;     border-radius: 8px;     color: white;     text-decoration: none;     }           How was this episode?      Overall       Good     Average     Bad     Engaging        Good     Average     Bad     Accurate        Good     Average     Bad     Tone       Good     Average     Bad     TranscriptFlute players hold a distinctive place in the world of music, enchanting audiences with their ability to produce a diverse array of tones and dynamics. The flute, a slender instrument made from gleaming metal or polished wood, may appear delicate, but it possesses a powerful voice that can range from hauntingly soft whispers to joyous, soaring melodies. With nimble fingers and expert breath control, flutists navigate intricate passages and convey profound emotions through their performances. Whether performing in orchestras, chamber ensembles, or as soloists, they captivate listeners with grace, precision, and the ability to transport them to realms of beauty and wonder.  This episode will explore the lives and careers of some of the greatest flute players of all time. Through their exceptional artistry, technical mastery, and expressive musicality, these musicians have left an indelible mark on the flute world. The episode will highlight their significant contributions to flute playing and pedagogy, showcasing how they have inspired generations of flutists and enriched the musical landscape. Geoffrey Gilbert stands as a monumental figure in the history of flute playing, revered for his exceptional musicianship, technical brilliance, and profound influence on the flute world. An English flutist, Gilbert’s career saw him assuming the role of principal flutist with several prestigious orchestras, including the London Symphony Orchestra and the Philharmonia Orchestra. His performances were characterized by an exquisite tone, flawless technique, and deeply expressive interpretations, leaving audiences spellbound.  Beyond his prowess as a performer, Gilbert was an ardent educator, imparting his vast knowledge and insights to students at renowned institutions worldwide. His pedagogical approach, emphasizing tone production, phrasing, and musicality, has had a lasting impact on the development of flutists. Many of his students have gone on to achieve significant success, spreading his teachings across the globe. Gilbert’s legacy as both a flutist and an educator continues to inspire and shape the flute community, ensuring that his influence endures through generations.  Shifting focus to another titan of the flute, Sir James Galway, often referred to as the “Man with the Golden Flute,” has captivated audiences worldwide with his virtuosity, expressive interpretations, and charismatic stage presence. Born in Belfast, Northern Ireland, Galway’s career has spanned several decades, during which he has become one of the most acclaimed flutists of his generation.  Galway’s extensive repertoire ranges from classical masterpieces to contemporary works and even popular tunes, all delivered with his signature warmth and precision. His recordings have achieved international acclaim, earning him numerous awards and accolades. Galway’s performances are marked by their technical brilliance, beautiful tone, and ability to connect deeply with audiences.  Beyond his solo career, Galway has collaborated with leading orchestras and musicians, leaving an indelible mark on the classical music landscape. His influence extends beyond performance; as a teacher and mentor, he continues to inspire generations of flutists with his passion and expertise. Sir James Galway’s contributions to the flute world have solidified his status as a living legend, celebrated for his extraordinary talent and enduring impact on music. Aurèle Nicolet, a Swiss flutist, distinguished himself as one of the leading flutists of the 20th century through his virtuosic technique and profound interpretations. Born in Neuchâtel, Switzerland, Nicolet honed his craft at the Paris Conservatoire under the tutelage of the renowned flutist Marcel Moyse. His career quickly ascended as he gained recognition as a soloist and chamber musician, performing with major orchestras and in prestigious venues around the globe.  Nicolet’s repertoire was notably diverse, spanning from the Baroque to contemporary music. He was especially revered for his performances of French and German flute music, bringing a depth of understanding and emotional resonance to each piece. His recordings remain a testament to his exceptional musicianship, continuing to inspire flutists with their technical brilliance and expressive power.  In addition to his illustrious performing career, Nicolet was a dedicated educator, serving on the faculty of the Basel Music Academy and the Freiburg University of Music. His teaching influenced generations of flutists, many of whom have gone on to successful careers in music. Aurèle Nicolet’s legacy is marked by his artistry, technique, and the profound musicality that he brought to every performance and teaching session.  Turning to another giant in the flute world, Jean-Pierre Rampal, a French virtuoso, is celebrated for his extraordinary talent and his pivotal role in popularizing the flute as a solo instrument. Born in Marseille, France, Rampal began his musical journey at a young age and quickly rose to prominence after winning first prize in flute at the Paris Conservatoire at just seventeen.  Rampal’s playing was characterized by exceptional technical skill, a beautiful tone, and expressive musicality. His repertoire encompassed a wide range of music, from Baroque to contemporary, with a particular affinity for Baroque music. Rampal played a significant role in bringing the flute to the forefront of the classical music world, commissioning new works and transcribing existing compositions to expand its repertoire.  His extensive recordings have left an indelible mark on the flute community, showcasing his artistry and technical prowess. With over one hundred recordings to his name, Rampal’s work remains highly regarded and continues to influence contemporary flute music. Beyond his performing career, he was a dedicated educator, serving on the faculties of the Paris Conservatoire and the Nice Conservatory. His instructional books on flute technique and interpretation are still widely used by flutists today.  Jean-Pierre Rampal’s contributions to the flute world are immense, and he is remembered as one of the greatest flutists in history. His exceptional skill, beautiful tone, and role in elevating the flute as a solo instrument have left a lasting legacy that continues to inspire flutists and music lovers worldwide. Marcel Moyse, a French flutist, is widely regarded as one of the most influential figures in the history of flute playing and pedagogy. Born in Saint-Amour, France, Moyse studied at the Paris Conservatoire and quickly gained recognition for his beautiful tone, expressive phrasing, and impeccable technique. His performing career included solo and chamber music engagements that captivated audiences with their emotional depth and technical precision.  However, Moyse's most enduring legacy lies in his contributions as a pedagogue. He revolutionized flute teaching with his innovative methods and influential instructional books, such as "Tone Development Through Interpretation," "De la Sonorité," and "Exercises Journaliers." These works have become essential reading for aspiring flutists, emphasizing the importance of a beautiful tone, expressive phrasing, and technical mastery. Moyse’s teaching philosophy focused on developing the musician's ability to convey emotion and character through their instrument.  His impact as a teacher was profound, with many of his students going on to become leading flutists and educators themselves. Moyse served on the faculty of the Paris Conservatoire and conducted masterclasses around the world, sharing his wisdom and insights with flutists of all levels. Marcel Moyse's legacy as a performer and educator continues to inspire and shape the flute community, ensuring his place as a monumental figure in the history of the instrument.  In stark contrast to Moyse's classical approach, Robert Dick, an American flutist and composer, has made significant contributions to contemporary music and extended techniques. Known for his innovative approach to flute playing, Dick has expanded the expressive possibilities of the instrument, pushing the boundaries of traditional flute techniques. His unique vocabulary of sounds includes multiphonics, glissandi, and percussive effects, creating rich and dynamic performances that challenge conventional expectations of flute music.  Dick's work encompasses a wide range of styles and genres, from classical to jazz to avant-garde. He is renowned for his pioneering spirit, constantly exploring new sonic landscapes and incorporating unconventional sounds and textures into his compositions. As a prolific composer, his catalog includes solo pieces, chamber music, and works for orchestra, reflecting his innovative approach to music.  In addition to his work as a performer and composer, Dick is a dedicated educator. He has written several books on flute technique and improvisation, sharing his unique approach with students and musicians worldwide. His teaching emphasizes creativity and exploration, encouraging flutists to push the limits of their instrument and discover new modes of expression.  Robert Dick's visionary contributions to flute playing have inspired a new generation of flutists to explore the expressive possibilities of the instrument. His pioneering work in contemporary music and extended techniques has left a lasting impact on the flute community, making him a seminal figure in the evolution of flute performance and pedagogy. Jeanne Baxtresser stands as a beacon of excellence in the world of flute playing, celebrated for her remarkable artistry and technical brilliance. Her illustrious career is highlighted by her tenure as the principal flutist of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra, a position she held for over a decade. During her time with the orchestra, Baxtresser's performances were characterized by their exquisite tone, impeccable phrasing, and captivating expressiveness, earning her widespread acclaim and admiration.  Beyond her orchestral achievements, Baxtresser is also an accomplished soloist and chamber musician, captivating audiences worldwide with her dynamic performances. Her contributions to the flute community extend far beyond the concert stage. As a dedicated educator, she has inspired countless flutists through her teaching at leading conservatories and music schools.   • Highlight their artistry and technical mastery
  • Showcase their contributions to flute pedagogy
  • Inspire generations of flutists

Transcript

Flute players hold a distinctive place in the world of music, enchanting audiences with their ability to produce a diverse array of tones and dynamics. The flute, a slender instrument made from gleaming metal or polished wood, may appear delicate, but it possesses a powerful voice that can range from hauntingly soft whispers to joyous, soaring melodies. With nimble fingers and expert breath control, flutists navigate intricate passages and convey profound emotions through their performances. Whether performing in orchestras, chamber ensembles, or as soloists, they captivate listeners with grace, precision, and the ability to transport them to realms of beauty and wonder.
This episode will explore the lives and careers of some of the greatest flute players of all time. Through their exceptional artistry, technical mastery, and expressive musicality, these musicians have left an indelible mark on the flute world. The episode will highlight their significant contributions to flute playing and pedagogy, showcasing how they have inspired generations of flutists and enriched the musical landscape. Geoffrey Gilbert stands as a monumental figure in the history of flute playing, revered for his exceptional musicianship, technical brilliance, and profound influence on the flute world. An English flutist, Gilbert’s career saw him assuming the role of principal flutist with several prestigious orchestras, including the London Symphony Orchestra and the Philharmonia Orchestra. His performances were characterized by an exquisite tone, flawless technique, and deeply expressive interpretations, leaving audiences spellbound.
Beyond his prowess as a performer, Gilbert was an ardent educator, imparting his vast knowledge and insights to students at renowned institutions worldwide. His pedagogical approach, emphasizing tone production, phrasing, and musicality, has had a lasting impact on the development of flutists. Many of his students have gone on to achieve significant success, spreading his teachings across the globe. Gilbert’s legacy as both a flutist and an educator continues to inspire and shape the flute community, ensuring that his influence endures through generations.
Shifting focus to another titan of the flute, Sir James Galway, often referred to as the “Man with the Golden Flute,” has captivated audiences worldwide with his virtuosity, expressive interpretations, and charismatic stage presence. Born in Belfast, Northern Ireland, Galway’s career has spanned several decades, during which he has become one of the most acclaimed flutists of his generation.
Galway’s extensive repertoire ranges from classical masterpieces to contemporary works and even popular tunes, all delivered with his signature warmth and precision. His recordings have achieved international acclaim, earning him numerous awards and accolades. Galway’s performances are marked by their technical brilliance, beautiful tone, and ability to connect deeply with audiences.
Beyond his solo career, Galway has collaborated with leading orchestras and musicians, leaving an indelible mark on the classical music landscape. His influence extends beyond performance; as a teacher and mentor, he continues to inspire generations of flutists with his passion and expertise. Sir James Galway’s contributions to the flute world have solidified his status as a living legend, celebrated for his extraordinary talent and enduring impact on music. Aurèle Nicolet, a Swiss flutist, distinguished himself as one of the leading flutists of the 20th century through his virtuosic technique and profound interpretations. Born in Neuchâtel, Switzerland, Nicolet honed his craft at the Paris Conservatoire under the tutelage of the renowned flutist Marcel Moyse. His career quickly ascended as he gained recognition as a soloist and chamber musician, performing with major orchestras and in prestigious venues around the globe.
Nicolet’s repertoire was notably diverse, spanning from the Baroque to contemporary music. He was especially revered for his performances of French and German flute music, bringing a depth of understanding and emotional resonance to each piece. His recordings remain a testament to his exceptional musicianship, continuing to inspire flutists with their technical brilliance and expressive power.
In addition to his illustrious performing career, Nicolet was a dedicated educator, serving on the faculty of the Basel Music Academy and the Freiburg University of Music. His teaching influenced generations of flutists, many of whom have gone on to successful careers in music. Aurèle Nicolet’s legacy is marked by his artistry, technique, and the profound musicality that he brought to every performance and teaching session.
Turning to another giant in the flute world, Jean-Pierre Rampal, a French virtuoso, is celebrated for his extraordinary talent and his pivotal role in popularizing the flute as a solo instrument. Born in Marseille, France, Rampal began his musical journey at a young age and quickly rose to prominence after winning first prize in flute at the Paris Conservatoire at just seventeen.
Rampal’s playing was characterized by exceptional technical skill, a beautiful tone, and expressive musicality. His repertoire encompassed a wide range of music, from Baroque to contemporary, with a particular affinity for Baroque music. Rampal played a significant role in bringing the flute to the forefront of the classical music world, commissioning new works and transcribing existing compositions to expand its repertoire.
His extensive recordings have left an indelible mark on the flute community, showcasing his artistry and technical prowess. With over one hundred recordings to his name, Rampal’s work remains highly regarded and continues to influence contemporary flute music. Beyond his performing career, he was a dedicated educator, serving on the faculties of the Paris Conservatoire and the Nice Conservatory. His instructional books on flute technique and interpretation are still widely used by flutists today.
Jean-Pierre Rampal’s contributions to the flute world are immense, and he is remembered as one of the greatest flutists in history. His exceptional skill, beautiful tone, and role in elevating the flute as a solo instrument have left a lasting legacy that continues to inspire flutists and music lovers worldwide. Marcel Moyse, a French flutist, is widely regarded as one of the most influential figures in the history of flute playing and pedagogy. Born in Saint-Amour, France, Moyse studied at the Paris Conservatoire and quickly gained recognition for his beautiful tone, expressive phrasing, and impeccable technique. His performing career included solo and chamber music engagements that captivated audiences with their emotional depth and technical precision.
However, Moyse's most enduring legacy lies in his contributions as a pedagogue. He revolutionized flute teaching with his innovative methods and influential instructional books, such as "Tone Development Through Interpretation," "De la Sonorité," and "Exercises Journaliers." These works have become essential reading for aspiring flutists, emphasizing the importance of a beautiful tone, expressive phrasing, and technical mastery. Moyse’s teaching philosophy focused on developing the musician's ability to convey emotion and character through their instrument.
His impact as a teacher was profound, with many of his students going on to become leading flutists and educators themselves. Moyse served on the faculty of the Paris Conservatoire and conducted masterclasses around the world, sharing his wisdom and insights with flutists of all levels. Marcel Moyse's legacy as a performer and educator continues to inspire and shape the flute community, ensuring his place as a monumental figure in the history of the instrument.
In stark contrast to Moyse's classical approach, Robert Dick, an American flutist and composer, has made significant contributions to contemporary music and extended techniques. Known for his innovative approach to flute playing, Dick has expanded the expressive possibilities of the instrument, pushing the boundaries of traditional flute techniques. His unique vocabulary of sounds includes multiphonics, glissandi, and percussive effects, creating rich and dynamic performances that challenge conventional expectations of flute music.
Dick's work encompasses a wide range of styles and genres, from classical to jazz to avant-garde. He is renowned for his pioneering spirit, constantly exploring new sonic landscapes and incorporating unconventional sounds and textures into his compositions. As a prolific composer, his catalog includes solo pieces, chamber music, and works for orchestra, reflecting his innovative approach to music.
In addition to his work as a performer and composer, Dick is a dedicated educator. He has written several books on flute technique and improvisation, sharing his unique approach with students and musicians worldwide. His teaching emphasizes creativity and exploration, encouraging flutists to push the limits of their instrument and discover new modes of expression.
Robert Dick's visionary contributions to flute playing have inspired a new generation of flutists to explore the expressive possibilities of the instrument. His pioneering work in contemporary music and extended techniques has left a lasting impact on the flute community, making him a seminal figure in the evolution of flute performance and pedagogy. Jeanne Baxtresser stands as a beacon of excellence in the world of flute playing, celebrated for her remarkable artistry and technical brilliance. Her illustrious career is highlighted by her tenure as the principal flutist of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra, a position she held for over a decade. During her time with the orchestra, Baxtresser's performances were characterized by their exquisite tone, impeccable phrasing, and captivating expressiveness, earning her widespread acclaim and admiration.

Baxtresser’s pedagogical approach emphasizes musicality, technique, and the development of a beautiful tone, shaping the next generation of flutists with her profound insights and expertise.
Her legacy as a flutist and educator continues to influence and inspire musicians worldwide, cementing her status as one of the finest flutists of her generation. Jeanne Baxtresser’s impact on the flute world is enduring, marked by her exceptional artistry and unwavering commitment to excellence.
